awd_abstract_narration:
This mathematics research project will investigate several connections between the local and global structure of a graph.  The connections under study have the form "if a graph does not contain this (small, local) object then the graph has a global structural property that most graphs do not possess." Such results, relating the non-existence of a local object and the presence of a global structure, can be of immense importance. Prior work established exactly this for a different kind of graph containment, namely graph minors, and this result has been of great interest and has had very many applications. This project seeks analogous results for induced subgraphs. 

The project investigates two such connections: the Gyarfas-Sumner conjecture, that for any tree and any complete graph, all graphs that contain neither of them can be vertex-partitioned into a small number of parts each containing no edge; and the Liebenau-Pilipczuk conjecture, that for any tree, all graphs not containing it or its complement admit two disjoint linear sets of vertices, either completely joined or with no edges between them. In both cases, "tree" cannot be replaced by any more general kind of graph. The first conjecture is one of several problems about so-called "chi-boundedness;" the Gyarfas-Sumner conjecture is the main chi-boundedness conjecture that is not yet resolved. The second conjecture grew from attempts to resolve the Erdos-Hajnal conjecture. The latter asserts that for any graph, all graphs not containing it have a clique or stable set of polynomial size, unlike general graphs, in which the largest clique or stable set might only have logarithmic size.  It is planned to investigate several conjectures of the form that for any graph, all graphs not containing this fixed graph or its complement have two large sets of vertices, either completely joined or joined by no edges (not sets of linear size, just of polynomial size).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the grant was to pursue the structure and coloring properties of H-free graphs, where H is some fixed graph (a graph is H-free if no induced subgraph is isomorphic to H); and in  particular,  to  work  on  the  Erdos-Hajnal  conjecture,  and  the  Gyarfas-Sumner  conjecture. The PI has made significant progress on both conjectures.

A graph is a set (of "vertices"), together with a set of some pairs of vertices (called "edges"). A graph G contains another graph H as an "induced subgraph" if there is an injective map from the vertex set of H into the vertex set of G carrying edges to edges and nonedges to nonedges. There are many results and conjectures that say that for any fixed graph H, the graphs G that do not contain H as an induced subgraph behave very differently from general graphs G.  One of the most well-known of these is the Erdos-Hajnal conjecture. This conjecture says that for every graph H, there exists c > 0 such that every H-free graph has a clique or stable set of cardinality at least |G|c, where |G| means the number of vertices of G. (A "clique" is a set of vertices all pairwise joined by edges, and a "stable set" is the opposite, a set of vertices where no pair are joined by an edge.) This conjecture was known to be true for all graphs H with at most four vertices, but is still open for some graphs H with five vertices; and the situation has been unchanged for many years. One major result of this project is that the PI (in joint work with Maria Chudnovsky, Alex Scott and Sophei Spirkl) settled the most prominent of the open five-vertex cases, namely when H is the five-vertex cycle.  The PI also proved several other results related to the Gyarfas-Sumner conjecture that are not detailed here.

A second famous open question about induced subgraphs is the Gyarfas-Sumner conjecture, dating from the 1980's. This conjecture says that for every forest H, there is a function f such that every H-free graph with largest clique of size k has chromatic number at most f (k), that is, its vertex set can be partitioned into f (k) stable sets. There is a stronger conjecture, due to Louis Esperet, that says that there is always such a function f which is a polynomial. The PI has been working on Esperet's conjecture, and has extended the (previously, very small) class of forests H for which it is known to be true, adding three new families of forests. A critical case is when H is the five-vertex path; this is the smallest graph not known to satisfy  Esperet's  conjecture,  and  the  smallest  graph  not  known  to  satisfy  the  Erdos-Hajnal conjecture. The PI (with co-authors) proved that the five-vertex path "very nearly" does indeed satisfy both conjectures.

Third, in joint work with his student Linda Cook, the PI found an exact description of all the graphs in which all induced cycles have the same length (when this length is at least seven). A group of researchers in Europe independently found the same result, and a joint paper is to be published.

Fourth, the PI proved two algorithmic results in 2020-21; how to test in polynomial time if a graph has an even induced cycle of length at least any fixed constant (joint with Linda Cook), and how to test in polynomial time whether every induced path between two given vertices in a graph has the same length (with Eli Berger and Sophie Spirkl).
